subject: Re: Prolegomena for a new QS font
msgSnippet: Some more comments, now that I have read the whole thing: I looked at the PDF at several sizes, and it holds up well down to about 9 point (an approximation).
messageBody:
Some more comments, now that I have read the whole thing:

I looked at the PDF at several sizes, and it holds up well down to about 9 point (an
approximation). But I find this true for most serif fonts on a screen: printed I think it
would look great at that size or even smaller.

I would have to agree about See and Zoo. I think the top curl on Zoo should be shorter (as
it normally starts at the baseline). I like the way Ye and Bay, while similar (though rotated)
are subtly different.

And I agree that the hooks on Fee Vie and May are unfamiliar and perhaps unnecessary.

As I noted before, an italicized Ooze would look just like Eat. I found Foot and Ooze
difficult to recognize at first, so maybe they could be more rounded (and still sufficiently
different from the other vowel sounds).

The 'er' and 'ia' diphthongs could be made a little wider, to match up with some of the
other diphthong characters.

I notice that the 'x' in 'except' has a serif on the bottom side, though it is the unvoiced
version. I suggest extending the leg (and serif) up for the unvoiced and down for the
voiced version.

The ball on the end of Day sometimes confused me, thinking that it was a period. I didn't
notice this with other characters. If it came to a point or a flat-ended serif it would be less
confusing.

Finally, I noticed what I think might be some misspellings (but I am not really sure):
in paragraph 1: 'intelligently' should have a Jay character instead of Gay
in paragraph 2: 'she's' should have a terminal Zoo
in paragraph 2: 'easily' should have a Zoo
in paragraph 3: 'current' should not have the Roe character after the 'er' diphthong
in paragraph 4: 'easy' should have a Zoo
in the last paragraph, should 'our' be 'out'?

For two words, 'noticed' and 'replaced' I would pronounce the terminal characters as Tea,
but I note in the QS manual that Read suggested using a single Day character for all
terminal 'ed' sounds. I think this makes sense for -d vs. -ed sounds in 'loved' and 'hated,'
but for unvoiced terminal 't' sounds I think Tea presents more accurate representation.
After all, Read does use both See and Zoo as plural terminals. Also, using Read's -ed rule
'added' in the 4th paragraph would have no Utter character, just two Day characters one
after the other (a rare doubling of characters in QS).

I hope this doesn't sound at all negative, but rather constructive. I found it a real pleasure
(and challenge) to read!

oliver


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "chuck030956" <chuck091956@o...> wrote:
>
> Thanks for the great effort.
>
> Over all I like it. It in general seems clean and very usable. One
> thing that seemed to make it less readable to me was the use of
> hooks on the M, F and V sound charaters. I do like the look of the
> small ball shaped ends on some of the letters. I do think a bit more
> difference between the "S" and "Z" letter would be helpfull. I know
> one is tall and the other is deep but my eye got lost when I saw
> their large simular shape. maybe uncurling the "Z" letter might do
> it.
>
> I realy like the form of the "L" sound letter, well done! The mAY
> and mY sound letters good good but I was a initialy comfused by the
> OIl and OUt sound letters. For me a little more slant on the OIl and
> OUt might be helpful.
>
> Again thanks for the great effort.
> Chuck
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "mcbroom1946"
> <mcbroom1946@y...> wrote:
> >
> > After promising to do so in a long-ago previous episode, I have
> finally
> > completed a new font to add to the Read Alphabet collection. But
> before
> > posting it, I thought it best to explain my intentions, and get
> your collective
> > feedback.
> >
> > Doing some frequency work on QS, I was looking at whole stories
> and essays
> > printed in existing fonts (Jerome and its variations), and saw in
> a sudden
> > blinding revelation that the original QS script --- aping, as it
> does, our Mr.
> > Read's elegant hand --- was in fact not appropriate for large,
> printed bodies of
> > text.
> >
> > For, even though I love Read for its logical shapes, its grace,
> and its pleasure
> > in handwriting, I feel now that for an alphabet to prosper, it
> must be able to
> > morph itself into alternative fonts that can either whisper or
> shout, waltz or
> > march, wax poetic or prosaic as the need arises. I mean, would
> anyone read
> > the Times every morning (or an Agatha Christie every night) if
> they were
> > printed in Gothic script or Spencerian penmanship?
> >
> > Let's face it. After almost 40 years before the world, QS has
> not "taken off"
> > except among we happy few. Why is that? Is there something we
> could learn
> > from traditional typography? After all, though our fore-fathers
> bollixed up any
> > natural correspondence of shapes and sounds, they might not have
> been
> > total fools.
> >
> > So I looked at the classic typefaces that we have been employing
> in Western
> > printing for the last 200 years, and wondered if their styles and
> shapes could
> > be transformed to capture the essence of Mr. Read's originally-
> hand-drawn
> > characters. And I was amazed to discover that, yes, I think they
> can.
> >
> > My new QS font is based upon a font called "Century Schoolbook,"
> a face
> > which all Americans of a certain age should remember from their
> first reading
> > lessons: "See Dick run. Run, Dick, run!" I thought it would make
> an
> > appropriate "primer" for learning to "read Read."
> >
> > I have just posted a brief "Fish Story" in the Text folder of the
> Files Section,
> > which I would hope you all will have the time and curiosity to
> peruse. Please
> > let me know if it "communicates" to you. If you can, try viewing
> it at different
> > sizes too - as if you were reading the morning paper, instead of a
> bronze
> > plaque.
> >
> > After your feedback, I will post the completed font or - depending
> on your
> > learned opinions - just go sulking off into the internet night.
> It's up to you all.
